page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Local History in Birtley is very interesting. It had its origins back in the llth Century but it did not become important until the turn of the century as the trades of coal mines, salt mines, brick yards and iron works expanded. In 1914 the area known as Elisabethville was turned into a Hospital and camp for the Belgian refugees. The factory of Turney Wylde on Elisabeth Avenue was also a hostel and all the surrounding streets had wooden huts housing the refugees. After the first World War the hospital was converted into a school which was demolished in 1982. Devon Autos factory was formerly used as a soup kitchen for local families during the war years. Most of old Birtley is centred around 'Charlie Perkins Monument' and is now a conservation area.
